## Description {#details}

This file implements the new LLVM&#39;s Global <a href="/docs/api/classes/llvm/value">Value</a> Numbering pass.

GVN partitions values computed by a function into congruence classes. Values ending up in the same congruence class are guaranteed to be the same for every execution of the program. In that respect, congruency is a compile-time approximation of equivalence of values at runtime. The algorithm implemented here uses a sparse formulation and it&#39;s based on the ideas described in the paper: &quot;A Sparse Algorithm for Predicated Global Value Numbering&quot; from Karthik Gargi.

A brief overview of the algorithm: The algorithm is essentially the same as the standard RPO value numbering algorithm (a good reference is the paper &quot;SCC based value numbering&quot; by L. Taylor Simpson) with one major difference: The RPO algorithm proceeds, on every iteration, to process every reachable block and every instruction in that block. This is because the standard RPO algorithm does not track what things have the same value number, it only tracks what the value number of a given operation is (the mapping is operation -&gt; value number). Thus, when a value number of an operation changes, it must reprocess everything to ensure all uses of a value number get updated properly. In constrast, the sparse algorithm we use <em>also</em> tracks what operations have a given value number (IE it also tracks the reverse mapping from value number -&gt; operations with that value number), so that it only needs to reprocess the instructions that are affected when something&#39;s value number changes. The vast majority of complexity and code in this file is devoted to tracking what value numbers could change for what instructions when various things happen. The rest of the algorithm is devoted to performing symbolic evaluation, forward propagation, and simplification of operations based on the value numbers deduced so far

In order to make the GVN mostly-complete, we use a technique derived from &quot;Detection of Redundant Expressions: A Complete and Polynomial-time
Algorithm in SSA&quot; by R.R. Pai. The source of incompleteness in most SSA based GVN algorithms is related to their inability to detect equivalence between phi of ops (IE phi(a+b, c+d)) and op of phis (phi(a,c) + phi(b, d)). We resolve this issue by generating the equivalent &quot;phi of ops&quot; form for each op of phis we see, in a way that only takes polynomial time to resolve.

We also do not perform elimination by using any published algorithm. All published algorithms are O(Instructions). Instead, we use a technique that is O(number of operations with the same value number), enabling us to skip trying to eliminate things that have unique value numbers.

<Link id="l00001" /><CodeLine lineNumber="1"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===- NewGVN.cpp - Global Value Numbering Pass ---------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00002" /><CodeLine lineNumber="2"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00003" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Part of the LLVM Project, under the Apache License v2.0 with LLVM Exceptions.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00004" /><CodeLine lineNumber="4"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// See https://llvm.org/LICENSE.txt for license information.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00005" /><CodeLine lineNumber="5"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// SPDX-License-Identifier: Apache-2.0 WITH LLVM-exception</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00006" /><CodeLine lineNumber="6"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00007" /><CodeLine lineNumber="7"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00008" /><CodeLine lineNumber="8"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00009" /><CodeLine lineNumber="9"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// \\file</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00010" /><CodeLine lineNumber="10"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// This file implements the new LLVM&#39;s Global Value Numbering pass.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00011" /><CodeLine lineNumber="11"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// GVN partitions values computed by a function into congruence classes.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00012" /><CodeLine lineNumber="12"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Values ending up in the same congruence class are guaranteed to be the same</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00013" /><CodeLine lineNumber="13"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// for every execution of the program. In that respect, congruency is a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00014" /><CodeLine lineNumber="14"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// compile-time approximation of equivalence of values at runtime.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00015" /><CodeLine lineNumber="15"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The algorithm implemented here uses a sparse formulation and it&#39;s based</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00016" /><CodeLine lineNumber="16"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// on the ideas described in the paper:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00017" /><CodeLine lineNumber="17"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// &quot;A Sparse Algorithm for Predicated Global Value Numbering&quot; from</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00018" /><CodeLine lineNumber="18"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Karthik Gargi.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00019" /><CodeLine lineNumber="19"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00020" /><CodeLine lineNumber="20"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// A brief overview of the algorithm: The algorithm is essentially the same as</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00021" /><CodeLine lineNumber="21"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// the standard RPO value numbering algorithm (a good reference is the paper</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00022" /><CodeLine lineNumber="22"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// &quot;SCC based value numbering&quot; by L. Taylor Simpson) with one major difference:</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00023" /><CodeLine lineNumber="23"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// The RPO algorithm proceeds, on every iteration, to process every reachable</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00024" /><CodeLine lineNumber="24"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// block and every instruction in that block.  This is because the standard RPO</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00025" /><CodeLine lineNumber="25"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// algorithm does not track what things have the same value number, it only</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00026" /><CodeLine lineNumber="26"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// tracks what the value number of a given operation is (the mapping is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00027" /><CodeLine lineNumber="27"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// operation -&gt; value number).  Thus, when a value number of an operation</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00028" /><CodeLine lineNumber="28"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// changes, it must reprocess everything to ensure all uses of a value number</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00029" /><CodeLine lineNumber="29"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// get updated properly.  In constrast, the sparse algorithm we use &#42;also&#42;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00030" /><CodeLine lineNumber="30"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// tracks what operations have a given value number (IE it also tracks the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00031" /><CodeLine lineNumber="31"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// reverse mapping from value number -&gt; operations with that value number), so</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00032" /><CodeLine lineNumber="32"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// that it only needs to reprocess the instructions that are affected when</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00033" /><CodeLine lineNumber="33"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// something&#39;s value number changes.  The vast majority of complexity and code</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00034" /><CodeLine lineNumber="34"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// in this file is devoted to tracking what value numbers could change for what</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00035" /><CodeLine lineNumber="35"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// instructions when various things happen.  The rest of the algorithm is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00036" /><CodeLine lineNumber="36"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// devoted to performing symbolic evaluation, forward propagation, and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00037" /><CodeLine lineNumber="37"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// simplification of operations based on the value numbers deduced so far</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00038" /><CodeLine lineNumber="38"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00039" /><CodeLine lineNumber="39"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// In order to make the GVN mostly-complete, we use a technique derived from</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00040" /><CodeLine lineNumber="40"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// &quot;Detection of Redundant Expressions: A Complete and Polynomial-time</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00041" /><CodeLine lineNumber="41"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// Algorithm in SSA&quot; by R.R. Pai.  The source of incompleteness in most SSA</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00042" /><CodeLine lineNumber="42"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// based GVN algorithms is related to their inability to detect equivalence</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00043" /><CodeLine lineNumber="43"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// between phi of ops (IE phi(a+b, c+d)) and op of phis (phi(a,c) + phi(b, d)).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00044" /><CodeLine lineNumber="44"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// We resolve this issue by generating the equivalent &quot;phi of ops&quot; form for</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00045" /><CodeLine lineNumber="45"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// each op of phis we see, in a way that only takes polynomial time to resolve.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00046" /><CodeLine lineNumber="46"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">///</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00047" /><CodeLine lineNumber="47"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// We also do not perform elimination by using any published algorithm.  All</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00048" /><CodeLine lineNumber="48"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// published algorithms are O(Instructions). Instead, we use a technique that</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00049" /><CodeLine lineNumber="49"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// is O(number of operations with the same value number), enabling us to skip</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00050" /><CodeLine lineNumber="50"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">/// trying to eliminate things that have unique value numbers.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00051" /><CodeLine lineNumber="51"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00052" /><CodeLine lineNumber="52"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//===----------------------------------------------------------------------===//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00053" /><CodeLine lineNumber="53"></CodeLine>

<Link id="l00253" /><CodeLine lineNumber="253"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00254" /><CodeLine lineNumber="254"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Congruence classes represent the set of expressions/instructions</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00255" /><CodeLine lineNumber="255"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// that are all the same &#42;during some scope in the function&#42;.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00256" /><CodeLine lineNumber="256"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// That is, because of the way we perform equality propagation, and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00257" /><CodeLine lineNumber="257"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// because of memory value numbering, it is not correct to assume</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00258" /><CodeLine lineNumber="258"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// you can willy-nilly replace any member with any other at any</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00259" /><CodeLine lineNumber="259"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// point in the function.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00260" /><CodeLine lineNumber="260"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00261" /><CodeLine lineNumber="261"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For any Value in the Member set, it is valid to replace any dominated member</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00262" /><CodeLine lineNumber="262"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// with that Value.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00263" /><CodeLine lineNumber="263"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00264" /><CodeLine lineNumber="264"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Every congruence class has a leader, and the leader is used to symbolize</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00265" /><CodeLine lineNumber="265"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// instructions in a canonical way (IE every operand of an instruction that is a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00266" /><CodeLine lineNumber="266"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// member of the same congruence class will always be replaced with leader</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00267" /><CodeLine lineNumber="267"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// during symbolization).  To simplify symbolization, we keep the leader as a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00268" /><CodeLine lineNumber="268"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// constant if class can be proved to be a constant value.  Otherwise, the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00269" /><CodeLine lineNumber="269"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// leader is the member of the value set with the smallest DFS number.  Each</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00270" /><CodeLine lineNumber="270"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// congruence class also has a defining expression, though the expression may be</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00271" /><CodeLine lineNumber="271"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// null.  If it exists, it can be used for forward propagation and reassociation</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00272" /><CodeLine lineNumber="272"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// of values.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00273" /><CodeLine lineNumber="273"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00274" /><CodeLine lineNumber="274"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For memory, we also track a representative MemoryAccess, and a set of memory</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00275" /><CodeLine lineNumber="275"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// members for MemoryPhis (which have no real instructions). Note that for</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00276" /><CodeLine lineNumber="276"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// memory, it seems tempting to try to split the memory members into a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00277" /><CodeLine lineNumber="277"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// MemoryCongruenceClass or something.  Unfortunately, this does not work</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00278" /><CodeLine lineNumber="278"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// easily.  The value numbering of a given memory expression depends on the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00279" /><CodeLine lineNumber="279"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// leader of the memory congruence class, and the leader of memory congruence</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00280" /><CodeLine lineNumber="280"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// class depends on the value numbering of a given memory expression.  This</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00281" /><CodeLine lineNumber="281"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// leads to wasted propagation, and in some cases, missed optimization.  For</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00282" /><CodeLine lineNumber="282"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// example: If we had value numbered two stores together before, but now do not,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00283" /><CodeLine lineNumber="283"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// we move them to a new value congruence class.  This in turn will move at one</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00284" /><CodeLine lineNumber="284"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// of the memorydefs to a new memory congruence class.  Which in turn, affects</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00285" /><CodeLine lineNumber="285"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the value numbering of the stores we just value numbered (because the memory</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00286" /><CodeLine lineNumber="286"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// congruence class is part of the value number).  So while theoretically</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00287" /><CodeLine lineNumber="287"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// possible to split them up, it turns out to be &#42;incredibly&#42; complicated to get</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00288" /><CodeLine lineNumber="288"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// it to work right, because of the interdependency.  While structurally</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00289" /><CodeLine lineNumber="289"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// slightly messier, it is algorithmically much simpler and faster to do what we</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00290" /><CodeLine lineNumber="290"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// do here, and track them both at once in the same class.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l00291" /><CodeLine lineNumber="291"><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Note: The default iterators for this class iterate over values</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l03566" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3566"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// It&#39;s not enough that any given field be less than - we have sets</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03567" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3567"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// of fields that need to be evaluated together to give a proper ordering.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03568" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3568"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For example, if you have;</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03569" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3569"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// DFS (1, 3)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03570" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3570"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Val 0</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03571" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3571"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// DFS (1, 2)</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03572" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3572"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Val 50</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03573" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3573"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// We want the second to be less than the first, but if we just go field</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03574" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3574"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// by field, we will get to Val 0 &lt; Val 50 and say the first is less than</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03575" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3575"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the second. We only want it to be less than if the DFS orders are equal.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03576" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3576"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03577" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3577"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Each LLVM instruction only produces one value, and thus the lowest-level</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03578" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3578"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// differentiator that really matters for the stack (and what we use as a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03579" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3579"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// replacement) is the local dfs number.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03580" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3580"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Everything else in the structure is instruction level, and only affects</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03581" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3581"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the order in which we will replace operands of a given instruction.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03582" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3582"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03583" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3583"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// For a given instruction (IE things with equal dfsin, dfsout, localnum),</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03584" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3584"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// the order of replacement of uses does not matter.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03585" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3585"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// IE given,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03586" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3586"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//  a = 5</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03587" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3587"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">//  b = a + a</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03588" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3588"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When you hit b, you will have two valuedfs with the same dfsin, out, and</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03589" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3589"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// localnum.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03590" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3590"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The .val will be the same as well.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03591" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3591"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// The .u&#39;s will be different.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03592" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3592"><span class="doxyHighlight">    </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// You will replace both, and it does not matter what order you replace them</span></CodeLine>

<Link id="l03862" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3862"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// This is a non-standard eliminator. The normal way to eliminate is</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03863" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3863"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// to walk the dominator tree in order, keeping track of available</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03864" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3864"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// values, and eliminating them.  However, this is mildly</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03865" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3865"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// pointless. It requires doing lookups on every instruction,</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03866" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3866"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// regardless of whether we will ever eliminate it.  For</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03867" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3867"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// instructions part of most singleton congruence classes, we know we</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03868" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3868"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// will never eliminate them.</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03869" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3869"></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03870" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3870"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// Instead, this eliminator looks at the congruence classes directly, sorts</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03871" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3871"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// them into a DFS ordering of the dominator tree, and then we just</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03872" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3872"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// perform elimination straight on the sets by walking the congruence</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03873" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3873"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// class member uses in order, and eliminate the ones dominated by the</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03874" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3874"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// last member.   This is worst case O(E log E) where E = number of</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03875" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3875"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// instructions in a single congruence class.  In theory, this is all</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03876" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3876"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// instructions.   In practice, it is much faster, as most instructions are</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03877" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3877"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// either in singleton congruence classes or can&#39;t possibly be eliminated</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03878" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3878"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// anyway (if there are no overlapping DFS ranges in class).</span></CodeLine>
<Link id="l03879" /><CodeLine lineNumber="3879"><span class="doxyHighlight">  </span><span class="doxyHighlightComment">// When we find something not dominated, it becomes the new leader</span></CodeLine>
